topics.heading: The Hound of the Baskervilles - Part 3 Questions

questions.question:
Who said the following words and to whom?
It helped us to realize the horror of this woman’s life when we saw the eagerness and joy with which she laid us on her husband’s track.
questions.explanation: Dr. Watson is the narrator of the story. And the quoted words denote the observation about Mrs. Stapleton. 'Us' refers to Dr. Watson himself, Holmes, and Lestrade together. They all had set out for the old tin mine where Stapleton was expected to be found.

questions.question: What is the meaning of “Quagmire”?
options: a soft boggy area of land that gives way underfoot.
questions.explanation: This question is self-explanatory.

questions.question: What was Jack Stapleton’s refuge in case of a crisis according to Mrs. Stapleton?
options: an old iron mine on an island in the heart of the mire
A rugged cobalt mine on an island in the heart of the mire
an old tin mine on an island at the end of the mire
an old tin mine on an island in the heart of the mire
questions.explanation: There is but one place where he could have fled,” she answered. “There is an old tin mine on an island in the heart of the mire. It was there that he kept his hound and there also he had made preparations so that he might have a refuge.

questions.question: Where was Lestrade after the interaction with Mrs. Stapleton?
options: He left for the Baskerville Hall with Holmes
He stayed back at the Merripit House with Dr. Watson
He went towards the Grimpen Mire
questions.explanation: Meanwhile we left Lestrade in possession of the house while Holmes and I went back with the baronet to Baskerville Hall.

questions.question: What was Sir Henry’s condition long after the confrontation with the Hound?
options: He remained unconscious for two days at the Baskerville Hall
He panicked because he had a nervous breakdown

questions.question:
What is the Author’s purpose behind making Dr. Watson, the narrator of the story say the following words:
And now I come rapidly to the conclusion of this singular narrative, in which I have tried to make the reader share those dark fears and vague surmises which clouded our lives so long and ended in such a tragic manner.
options: To assure the readers that the resolution is quite close.
To ensure that the readers give attention to the ending and not get bored with the flow of the narrative
questions.explanation: The question is self-explanatory.

questions.question: “Meyers, Toronto” was printed on the:
options: Old black boot of Sir Henry which Holmes and his team found on the way to the old tin mine
questions.explanation: He held an old black boot in the air. “Meyers, Toronto,” was printed on the leather inside. “It is worth a mud bath,” he said. “It is our friend Sir Henry’s missing boot.” “Thrown there by Stapleton in his flight.” “Exactly. He retained it in his hand after using it to set the hound upon the track. He fled when he knew the game was up, still clutching it. And he hurled it away at this point of his flight. We know at least that he came so far in safety.”

questions.explanation: “A dog!” said Holmes. “By Jove, a curly-haired spaniel. Poor Mortimer will never see his pet again.”
